quotes.topic_title: Notion’s “lost years” and sugar-coated broccoli
quotes.text: Our realization is actually let's hide our vision, which is everybody can create their software in the form factor that people do care.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A practical go-to-market lesson: package an ambitious platform vision inside a product category users already want.

quotes.topic_title: Notion’s “lost years” and sugar-coated broccoli
quotes.text: We called it sugar-coated broccoli. People don't want to eat the broccoli but people like sugar, so it gave them the sugar then hide your broccoli inside of it.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable framework for driving adoption: lead with immediate user value (“sugar”) while embedding the deeper capability (“broccoli”).

quotes.topic_title: Notion’s “lost years” and sugar-coated broccoli
quotes.text: Too much of yourself. Then there's no users. Then you're just doing our project. And too much for business, you're building a commodity.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A balancing model for product strategy: avoid the extremes of pure personal vision (no market) and pure monetization (no differentiation).

quotes.topic_title: Notion’s “lost years” and sugar-coated broccoli
quotes.text: Tools are extensions of us. And once they extend us, once we shape them, once we bring them to world, they can come back to shape us.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A mental model for product impact: tools don’t just help users do work—they influence how users think and behave over time.

quotes.topic_title: Tools shape humans, and vice versa
quotes.text: The way you think about Notion, it's almost like a philosophy of how to work and be versus just a productivity tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames product-building as designing a philosophy of work/behavior, not just features—useful for practitioners defining product vision and positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Tools shape humans, and vice versa
quotes.text: Tools are extensions of us.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concise mental model for evaluating tools by how they amplify human capability, guiding product decisions toward empowerment rather than automation alone.

quotes.topic_title: Tools shape humans, and vice versa
quotes.text: And once they extend us, once we shape them, once we bring them to world, they can come back to shape us.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Highlights a feedback loop: tools change user behavior and thinking, a practical lens for anticipating second-order effects of product design.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We talk about the first three to four years of Notion that he describes as the lost years, how he was able to get into a great school in China by winning a programming contest, the joy and suffering of building a successful horizontal product, plus his approach to staying lean and craft and making trade-offs and also leadership.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights several practitioner-relevant themes—staying lean, craft, trade-offs, and the unique challenges of building a horizontal product.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, a wild story about how Notion almost died during COVID because the one database that everything lived in almost ran out of space.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete near-failure example that underscores infrastructure risk and single points of failure during rapid growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features, and Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth lever and frames the goal as increasing velocity without sacrificing analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Actionable focus on reducing experiment cycle time via better stats, self-serve analysis, and standardized reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A-B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Introduces the “A-B testing flywheel” mental model: sharing learnings fuels more/better experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of it as mission control for your entire product organization.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Airtable ProductCentral)
quotes.context: Memorable framing for consolidating product operations into a single system of record to reduce fragmentation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And because it's built on Airtable's no-code platform, you can customize every workflow to match exactly how your team works.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Airtable ProductCentral)
quotes.context: Actionable principle: prefer adaptable systems that fit your team’s workflows over forcing teams into rigid tools.

quotes.topic_title: Ivan’s early life: contests, art, and coding
quotes.text: I'm from somewhere else and in order to go into good school in the capital, you need to win some kind of competition.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete, leverage-based strategy: use competitions as a non-traditional credential to unlock access and mobility.

quotes.topic_title: Ivan’s early life: contests, art, and coding
quotes.text: And there's different paths. You can get at math or you can get at programming like Information Olympiad.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Offers a simple framework for choosing among multiple “credential paths” based on strengths and available competitions.

quotes.topic_title: Ivan’s early life: contests, art, and coding
quotes.text: I was really into computer games at the time so of course I picked the programming one so I can play computers all day long.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive career insight: leaning into intrinsic motivation (even “unserious” interests) can drive skill acquisition and opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: Ivan’s early life: contests, art, and coding
quotes.text: By the time I graduated college, I realized most of my friends are artists. They need to make their websites, get web portfolio made. And I'm the only nerd in my art friend circle so I made three or four websites and realized, "Oh, actually people don't know how to create with the software media, computing media."
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A specific example of discovering a product gap by serving a niche community firsthand and noticing repeated unmet needs.

quotes.topic_title: Ivan’s early life: contests, art, and coding
quotes.text: So that got me into want to create a product like Notion today which it allow more people to create tools, create software for their daily work and life.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Captures the core product thesis: empower non-technical people to build and shape software for everyday use.

quotes.topic_title: Learning English and discovering computing pioneers
quotes.text: What you're missing is the context, the culture. So you have to watch SpongeBob or Simpsons to get a sense of humor essentially. You can understand jokes.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A practical method for learning real-world language fluency: prioritize cultural context (humor, references) over test-focused grammar.

quotes.topic_title: Learning English and discovering computing pioneers
quotes.text: Watching cartoons, it's probably the easiest way to do that.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A simple, actionable tactic for acquiring cultural English quickly through accessible media.

quotes.topic_title: Learning English and discovering computing pioneers
quotes.text: For them computing, there shouldn't be a separation between builders and users. It's the same medium.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A product philosophy/framework: design computing tools so users can also be creators, collapsing the builder–user divide.

quotes.topic_title: Learning English and discovering computing pioneers
quotes.text: If you are making software, if you know how to code or design, this is the highest leverage thing you can do for other people.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A leverage mental model for builders: focus on tools that multiply others’ capabilities rather than one-off outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Learning English and discovering computing pioneers
quotes.text: So giving them the ability to use computing to augment their problem-solving ability or their intellect, that just got me obsessed with this problem and I want to start a company like Notion.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A clear mission statement for tool-building: empower users to augment their thinking and problem-solving through software.

quotes.topic_title: Steve Jobs, Xerox PARC, and malleable software
quotes.text: Alto runs down the system called Smalltalk, which is there's no separation between users and users' app. There's no thing called application. Everything is malleable. You can change the tools.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A foundational product philosophy: design software so users can reshape tools directly, not just use fixed “apps.”

quotes.topic_title: Steve Jobs, Xerox PARC, and malleable software
quotes.text: Then people just instantly change the scroll bar direction for him.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concrete example of malleable software enabling rapid iteration and customization in the moment.

quotes.topic_title: Steve Jobs, Xerox PARC, and malleable software
quotes.text: He only saw the graphic user interface. He did not see the underlying object or the environment power.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive critique: focusing on surface UI can cause teams to miss deeper platform-level leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Steve Jobs, Xerox PARC, and malleable software
quotes.text: As the generation of Steve Jobs and Bill Gates made PC, personal computing, popular and they stuck with this an application framework rather than the Smalltalk object framework. Then that has all the apps we have today and has the SaaS route we have today.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A causal model linking early platform choices (apps vs. objects) to today’s app-centric SaaS ecosystem.

quotes.topic_title: Lost years: pivots, rebuilds, and throwing away code
quotes.text: We tried that a couple of years and learned that actually most people just don't care. The majority of people, they wake up, they have report due, they need to get their job done, they don't care creating software to optimize whatever they're doing. They don't care.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A blunt reminder to anchor product bets in what mainstream users urgently need, not what builders find exciting.

quotes.topic_title: Lost years: pivots, rebuilds, and throwing away code
quotes.text: our realization is actually, let's hide our vision, which is everybody can create their software, in the form factor that people do care.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A practical go-to-market/product-shaping tactic: package a deep vision inside a familiar, high-demand use case.

quotes.topic_title: Lost years: pivots, rebuilds, and throwing away code
quotes.text: We call it sugar-coated broccoli. People don't want to eat the broccoli but people like sugar, so give them the sugar then hide the broccoli inside of it.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for making powerful but “hard to want” capabilities adoptable via an appealing surface experience.

quotes.topic_title: Lost years: pivots, rebuilds, and throwing away code
quotes.text: It's very much so because sense of maturation is you don't see the world just from your perspective but from outside your perspective.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A product-building lesson on developing user empathy as a core founder skill, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Lost years: pivots, rebuilds, and throwing away code
quotes.text: And then we realize because it's so new, it's just so unstable. It don't know where the bug come from. It's from your source code or from the underlying libraries? Then we have to restart the company, rebuild the whole thing. Otherwise, we're going to run out of time.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concrete example of how an early technical foundation choice can force a full reset—and why rebuilding can be the fastest path.

quotes.topic_title: Staying alive: mom’s loan, layoffs, and Japan reset
quotes.text: Then we run out of the money so, "Hey mom, can I borrow that just to bridge us?" Which she did. I'm really grateful for that.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concrete example of using a personal bridge loan to extend runway and keep the company alive.

quotes.topic_title: Staying alive: mom’s loan, layoffs, and Japan reset
quotes.text: How do you last here so long? Because the thing you want to create does not exist, which what is called Notions. It's a Lego for software.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A motivating mental model: endurance comes from pursuing something you believe fundamentally should exist, framed as a clear product metaphor.

quotes.topic_title: Staying alive: mom’s loan, layoffs, and Japan reset
quotes.text: We build on the wrong technical foundation. And if we continue to build on the wrong ones, we're going to run out of money. Company won't exist. So we decided to lay off everybody.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A hard operational call: when the foundation is wrong, cutting costs drastically can be the only way to buy time to rebuild correctly.

quotes.topic_title: Staying alive: mom’s loan, layoffs, and Japan reset
quotes.text: Let's just go somewhere that we've never been to change the scenery a little bit.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable reset tactic for morale and focus during a rebuild phase.

quotes.topic_title: Staying alive: mom’s loan, layoffs, and Japan reset
quotes.text: We actually travel around the world for a while just to change it up, me and Sam just coding every day and design every day. That's some of the happiest moments. Birthday every day.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive example that intense output and morale can improve by changing environment while staying extremely focused on the work.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for founders: reset, abstraction, and balance
quotes.text: Whenever I feel down, I just go to sleep and next day I'm just reset.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A simple, actionable tactic for enduring long uncertainty: use sleep as a reliable emotional and cognitive reset.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for founders: reset, abstraction, and balance
quotes.text: Definitely don't be afraid to reset. I think courage is quite important because oftentimes you're working on things don't matter, but momentum just took you there.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A warning against momentum-driven work and a call to proactively restart when you realize you’re optimizing the wrong thing.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for founders: reset, abstraction, and balance
quotes.text: Too much of yourself, then there's no users. Then you're just doing our project. You're just doing a research project. And too much for a business, you're building a commodity.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable spectrum model for balancing personal taste/values with market needs to avoid either irrelevance or commoditization.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for founders: reset, abstraction, and balance
quotes.text: I think the more interesting point here, it's like you can create progress through better abstractions. And that thing compounds faster, can catch up to all the things you build much quicker than you ever thought.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A mental model for why resets can be high-leverage: improved abstractions compound and can rapidly recover “lost” progress.

quotes.topic_title: Advice for founders: reset, abstraction, and balance
quotes.text: The kernel of things could be really small, but just like math. It can compound. It can have complex behavior that unlocks so much value and things for you.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concrete product-building principle: focus on a tiny, powerful kernel that can scale into complex, valuable behavior.

quotes.topic_title: What PMF felt like: gradual ramp and VC signals
quotes.text: I think going back to me and Simon, high is never that high, low is never that low, it never hit us as a binary state.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A contrarian framing of PMF as a non-binary, emotionally steady progression rather than a single breakthrough moment.

quotes.topic_title: What PMF felt like: gradual ramp and VC signals
quotes.text: And it's a very gradual ramp.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A simple mental model for PMF: look for compounding growth signals over time rather than a sudden step-change.

quotes.topic_title: What PMF felt like: gradual ramp and VC signals
quotes.text: It's a less of a milestone way to thinking about things. It's more just like, "Can we do the same that's in our head and better than we did last week?" way of thinking about things.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: An actionable weekly improvement loop that replaces milestone-chasing with continuous iteration against an internal quality bar.

quotes.topic_title: What PMF felt like: gradual ramp and VC signals
quotes.text: Investors start knocking on the door was like, I remember one day it's like there's a dog food, dog treats sent to our entire office. So first of all, office wasn't public, the address.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A vivid example of inbound investor intensity as an external signal that traction is becoming undeniable.

quotes.topic_title: What PMF felt like: gradual ramp and VC signals
quotes.text: I realize and one of the members is saying, "Ivan, what are you doing? You clearly don't need money. You're just trying to feel good to do external validation about this."
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Practical advice to avoid validation-seeking meetings that don’t improve the product, even when investor attention increases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're sending marketing campaigns, verification codes or account alerts, you need them to reach users reliably.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights reliability as the core requirement for any customer-communications system, regardless of message type.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 150,000 businesses, including eight of the top 10 largest tech companies globally, use Sinch's API to build messaging, email, and calling into their products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point that signals scale and credibility of an API platform.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of RCS as SMS 2.0.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Offers a simple mental model for product teams to quickly understand where RCS fits relative to SMS.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Instead of getting texts from a random number, your users will see your verified company name and logo without needing to download anything new.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Explains a practical UX/security benefit (verified identity + zero new app install) that can change messaging strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: US carriers are starting to adopt RCS.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Signals an ecosystem shift that practitioners can act on early (planning, experimentation, registration).

quotes.topic_title: Staying small: profitability, systems, and talent density
quotes.text: And you all know you're doing product management. The overhead is actually more from internal communication. It's really hard to get people's mind to be aligned on things, to see the world in the same way. And the part that you do need people, maybe you can solve better through systems, through better tools.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mental model: coordination costs often dominate, so invest in systems/tools before adding headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Staying small: profitability, systems, and talent density
quotes.text: Notion itself is a meta tool to build other tools. So we pretty much run everything on Notion. We use the same mindset to build our company.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Shows an actionable methodology: use your product internally as an operating system to reduce coordination overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Staying small: profitability, systems, and talent density
quotes.text: And accidentally, that keep our headcount low, keep our company profitable, which then puts you on a positive treadmill of you don't have to go for the next 18, 24 months to find money. You can just focus on building.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Connects profitability and small teams to a compounding advantage—more time building instead of fundraising.

quotes.topic_title: Staying small: profitability, systems, and talent density
quotes.text: And also because your team's small, we have this internal Notion called talent density. We don't try to track number of people but we try to track how talent-dense, revenue per employee we are.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete metric/framework for staying small: optimize for talent density and revenue per employee, not headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Staying small: profitability, systems, and talent density
quotes.text: I just believe better system is much better than brute force through people.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A contrarian operating principle: prefer improving systems over scaling via hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Small bus metaphor and office as creative studio
quotes.text: Internally we use the metaphor that Notion's a small bus. The bus, the smaller the bus, it's easier to turn corners, easier to accelerate, easier to maneuver. The bigger the bus it is, bigger the boat or bigger the bus, slow down.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why staying small increases organizational agility and speed.

quotes.topic_title: Small bus metaphor and office as creative studio
quotes.text: And as a leader in the company, you decide who sit around you on the bus seats. That dictates how fast our overall bus moves, dictate your work and life experience at this company because you pick your roommate, you pick your seat mates.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Actionable leadership advice: hiring and team composition directly shape both execution speed and culture.

quotes.topic_title: Small bus metaphor and office as creative studio
quotes.text: Therefore, most office, the top light feels like hospital. You're just like, "Oh, man." And the white is so pale and the floor is so dark. Why use some kind of cream, make floors more friendly colors? And don't use top light. Top light is evil.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Concrete, counterintuitive office-design guidance that ties physical environment choices to comfort and creativity.

quotes.topic_title: Small bus metaphor and office as creative studio
quotes.text: So the vision work we have is should feels like artist studio or should feel like your home. And that's why most our office furniture are home furnitures. It just feels cozy. That's more so people spend more time, feels more creative, juices flow better.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A clear methodology for designing offices as creative studios to increase time-in-office and creative output.

quotes.topic_title: Small bus metaphor and office as creative studio
quotes.text: But you have more visual improve from, at least for me from the eyes. If the chair looks ugly, the wall looks ugly, it hurts. So it's better to not have thing that hurts.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Aesthetic quality is framed as an ergonomic necessity—reducing “visual pain” to support sustained creative work.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless tools, craftsmanship, and trade-offs
quotes.text: We name our conference room after timeless tools in history.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concrete cultural practice that reinforces a product-building mindset focused on durability and toolmaking.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless tools, craftsmanship, and trade-offs
quotes.text: Because software, and especially tech, it's every six months, every 12 months cycle. We don't think enough about creating something that lasts. I care creating something that at least the form factor lasts longer than 18 month.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A counterpoint to short iteration cycles that sets a practical durability bar teams can aim for.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless tools, craftsmanship, and trade-offs
quotes.text: Craft is your skill set, your taste. Value is your personal value and how do you see the world.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A simple, reusable framework for evaluating product decisions through both capability (craft) and worldview (values).

quotes.topic_title: Timeless tools, craftsmanship, and trade-offs
quotes.text: It's like about apply your value to some technical know-how and to make more clever trade-offs to create something new and useful and just keep doing that.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: An actionable definition of craft as an iterative loop: values + know-how → smarter trade-offs → useful novelty.

quotes.topic_title: Timeless tools, craftsmanship, and trade-offs
quotes.text: I always feels like AI language model feels like a new type of wood. It feels like aluminum. It's a new type of material.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for treating new tech (AI) as a material that changes what trade-offs and products are feasible.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: storytelling at scale and authenticity
quotes.text: the world's not like you. The world don't care about you so you have to shave off the idealistic part of you to go something that's like the world actually cares, the sugar coat of broccoli. You have to hide the broccoli within something, the sugar pills.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A practical positioning framework: keep the core value (“broccoli”) but package it in a form the market will actually adopt (“sugar coat”).

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: storytelling at scale and authenticity
quotes.text: I'm pretty good at storytelling. So that's a one-to-one influence. But as a company grows, you realize you need to be one-to-many storytellers. That's a skill.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Highlights a leadership scaling shift: storytelling must evolve from individual persuasion to scalable, broadcast communication.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: storytelling at scale and authenticity
quotes.text: Then you realize it's a necessary craft for me to pick up in order to change the shape of the company, the business I'm building. I treat it like a craft.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: Actionable advice to deliberately practice leadership communication as a learnable craft tied to company evolution.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: storytelling at scale and authenticity
quotes.text: Every 12, 18 month, Notion's like a new company or at least they require different skill set coming from me. So I need to pick up new things. And it's an infinite game and infinite games are more fun.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for founder growth: treat the role as recurring “new game levels” requiring new skills over time.

quotes.topic_title: Leadership growth: storytelling at scale and authenticity
quotes.text: So deceiving is not truthful. You can fool other people once or twice, then there's no future. It has to be actually tied back to something genuinely the value creating or the exchange with the other person.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A contrarian take on marketing/positioning: persuasion must be grounded in real value exchange or it collapses long-term.

quotes.topic_title: Losing the way: hard-coded features vs Lego principles
quotes.text: Notion, we call Notion is Lego for software. We ship non-Lego pieces into our product.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A crisp articulation of a product philosophy (“Lego”) and the costly failure mode of violating it.

quotes.topic_title: Losing the way: hard-coded features vs Lego principles
quotes.text: It's like if you create this thing called a product or business, you attract people are value aligned to it. Then if you're trying to optimize too much on this competition revenue side of things, forced to introducing something anti-your-value, then the system, it's like there's organ rejection with your employees, with your customers.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“organ rejection”) for what happens when incentives push a company to ship against its core values.

quotes.topic_title: Losing the way: hard-coded features vs Lego principles
quotes.text: And you can get a better project management tool just by hard coding things like sprints, milestones, all those things into your product, or you can do it in the way the Notion are being, through Lego pieces.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A concrete trade-off framework between shipping fast via hard-coded features vs building reusable primitives that compound.

quotes.topic_title: Losing the way: hard-coded features vs Lego principles
quotes.text: So there's another saying that if you build in a Lego way inside Notion in the code base or product, the system work for you. If you're building non-Lego way, the system work against you.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: An actionable heuristic for engineering/product decisions: architecture aligned to first principles reduces friction; misalignment creates drag.

quotes.topic_title: Losing the way: hard-coded features vs Lego principles
quotes.text: That took nine months, a year to realize sometime.
quotes.speaker: Ivan Zhao
quotes.context: A sobering data point on how long it can take to recognize a strategic/product misstep even with strong feedback signals.
